Can we do better than the religious accounts of the origin of morality? Because, for obvious reasons, we have no historical record of a human society in the period before it had any standards of right and wrong, history cannot tell us the origins of morality. However, there is another mode of inquiry open to us. Given that human beings are [[social animal]]s, the origins of morality can plausibly be explored through examination of the social behaviour of non-humans animals and the evolutionary theory for such behaviour. Can we do better than the religious accounts of the origin of morality? Because, for obvious reasons, we have no historical record of a human society in the period before it had any standards of right and wrong, history cannot tell us the origins of morality. However, there is another mode of inquiry open to us. Given that human beings are [[social animal]]s, the origins of morality can plausibly be explored through examination of the social behaviour of non-human animals and the evolutionary theory for such behaviour. It has been asserted that, despite the apparent diversity of ethical practices, common themes across many human and non-human societies might include: obligations of [[kinship]], obligations of [[reciprocity]], and limitations on sexual behaviour.
     
Research in evolutionary theory applied to social behaviour, shows that evolution of species take into account [[altruism]] as a positive factor for the survival of the species. Some of this altruistic behaviour is explained by kin selection. Hamilton's rule describes the benefit of such altuism in terms of the product of the sacrificer's relatedness to the beneficiary and the benefit granted to the beneficiary minus the cost to the sacrificer. Should this sum be greater than zero a fitness gain will result from the sacrifice. When apparent altruism is not between kin, it may be based on reciprocity. A monkey will present its back to another monkey, who will pick out parasites; after a time the roles will be reversed. Such reciprocity will pay off, in evolutionary terms, as long as the costs of helping are less than the benefits of being helped and as long as animals will not gain in the long run by “cheating” - that is to say, by receiving favours without returning them.
